item.title: My First Mac
item.dc:creator: bdirgo
item.content:encoded:
This is the story of how I decided to take a look into how the other side lives. I looked at the prices of a new Mac laptop then I compared it to my savings account. Realizing that I would need to increase it by a few orders of magnitude I lowered my expectations in what I should be purchasing. I lowered my expectations as low as you could go and still have a laptop that you can use day-to-day. I found the sites everymac and lowendmac quite useful in making the decision of getting a PowerBook G4. Found one on eBay for $35 and all that’s wrong with it is it’s a little dinged up, and didn’t have OS X installed. No problem, another guy sells USB sticks with 10.5 on them. What system can’t boot from USB sticks? The PowerBook G4’s must be the only system that cannot boot from USB. Well, it can’t boot from USB without some OpenFirmware wizardry, and some unorthodox methods. So in case you are lost and have stumbled across my blog here's how I did it.

Boot into Open Firmware on your machine with a blank USB drive plugged in. First we have to figure out where that blank USB is located in the hardware. I think we can find hardware addresses with the command

dev / ls

As you can see in the picture above my hardware address for my USB was at

/pci@f4000000/ata-6@d/disk@0:2,\\:tbxi

write down that address, and set it to the boot-device with the commands,

setenv boot-device /pci@f4000000/ata-6@d/disk@0:2,\\:tbxi

then you remove the blank USB disk and replace it with the USB drive that has a bootable Mac OS X operating system. And finally boot into it with

mac-boot

Now I'm working from memory here, so as always Google is your friend.

I finally got it to boot from USB, but as it turned out the hard drive was corrupted. It was the kind of corrupted that Disk Utility would give it a pass, and then you get the OS installed it just doesn’t boot.

Back to eBay one last time, find a guy that sells PATA 2.5” drives preinstalled with everything that a budding PowerBook user would need. I double checked everything on the specs with the seller this time, and then installed the drive.

iFixit.com has a great instruction guide explaining how to go about replacing your hard drive.

[caption id="attachment_19" align="alignleft" width="410"] With the keyboard removed.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_17" align="alignright" width="307"] Look at how sexy those internals are! So well designed.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_9" align="alignleft" width="405"] Testing before I putt it all back together, it works![/caption] Finally after a few weeks of investigation, trial and error, I have a working Apple computer. I am very happy with this laptop. Sure the hardware is almost ten years old, and YouTube doesn’t stream, and I can’t install cool new apps from the Mac App store. But, god damn this keyboard is amazing, and did you see how sexy those internals are? Plus, there are plenty of determined PowerPC users out there. There are always ways to get what you need done. I mean heck even Dropbox supports G4 (.dmg warning). The experience of learning about the way another system is designed was half the fun in getting this. And it gave me something to write about, and to write on, for this blog. I would also like to point out that in the month that I’ve used the PowerBook since I fixed it, it has not once fluctuated in performance from “day one” (Somehow the battery still has a three hour charge). But the windows laptop that I have has needed to be restored twice. Consistency is king. I hope that this machine will hold me over till I have enough to spend on one of the new MacBook Air’s.

item.title: How would you control a slider using the built in gyroscope in Swift
item.dc:creator: bdirgo
item.content:encoded:
I'm building off of the Intro to iOS App Development with Swift class from Udacity. So we know how to create Labels, Actions, storyboards, and familiar with what a view controller is. And if any of my descriptions of the code are confusing I have included my code for the view controller at the bottom of the post. So to start I created a storyboard with some labels and a slider.

The numbers at the end of each of the labels are seperate so that we can change the numbers, and see what data the gyroscope can give us. I created IBOutlet's for each of these numbers and an outlet for the slider as well.

Looking at the documentation for the gyroscope in iOS lead me to CoreMotion. CoreMotion controls the output from the gyroscope, so to include it go to your projects page in Xcode -> General tab -> Linked Frameworks and Libraries. Click the plus and look for CoreMotion to add it to your project. Now that the framework is in your project you can import it to your code. In the view controller right under import UIKit, write "import CoreMotion". In addition to importing it to our view controller we have to initialize the CoreMotion Motion Manager. I put this declaration right under the IBOutlets so that every function could use the motion manager, it is initialized by calling CMMotionManager() and assigning it to a variable.

Now inside the view did load we need to set up the motion Manager to look for gyroscopic movement. So we set the update interval with gyroUpdateInterval to how many times it should update per second. And then we tell the motion manager to start recording data by passing in a function as a variable into startGyroUpdatesToQueue, called a Handler, that will take in CMGyroData and output Void. I put all of this into another function called outputGyroData.

First I update the labels on the storyboard with the current data from the gyroscope by converting them to strings. But then ran into a problem when looking at the slider. The slider value is a float while the gyro data is a double, simply putting double data into a float function results in an error from Xcode. So first I took the gyroData converted it to an NSString, used a floatValue function to convert it to a float, and then used that to input the gyro data into the slider.

The Gyro can not be simulated in the simulator on the Mac so you need to test this app on a physical device to test if this is the correct code. 


 //
 // ViewController.swift
 // Slider
 //
 // Created by Benjamin Dirgo on 9/13/15.
 // Copyright (c) 2015 Benjamin Dirgo. All rights reserved.
 //
import UIKit
import CoreMotion
class ViewController: UIViewController {
@IBOutlet weak var xRot: UILabel!
 @IBOutlet weak var yRot: UILabel!
 @IBOutlet weak var zRot: UILabel!
 @IBOutlet weak var slider: UISlider!
 //Load Motion Manager to log the movements of the Gyro
 var motionManager = CMMotionManager()
override func viewDidLoad() {
 //Zero out Labels and Slider
 xRot.text = "0"
 yRot.text = "0"
 zRot.text = "0"
 slider.setValue(0.5, animated: true)
//Set motion manager properties
 motionManager.gyroUpdateInterval = 0.2
//Start recording data
 motionManager.startGyroUpdatesToQueue(NSOperationQueue.currentQueue(), withHandler: {
 (gyroData: CMGyroData!, error: NSError!) -> Void in
 self.outputGyroData(gyroData.rotationRate)
 if error != nil {
 println("Error in startup of data capture")
 }
 })
super.viewDidLoad()
 // Do any additional setup after loading the view, typically from a nib.
 }
func outputGyroData(gyroData: CMRotationRate) {
 xRot?.text = "\(gyroData.x).2fg"
 yRot?.text = "\(gyroData.y).2fg"
 zRot?.text = "\(gyroData.z).2fg"
 var xFloat : Float = NSString(string: "\(gyroData.x)").floatValue
 slider.setValue(xFloat, animated: true)
 }
override func didReceiveMemoryWarning() {
 super.didReceiveMemoryWarning()
 // Dispose of any resources that can be recreated.
 }
}
